page.title: 11Hawarden Airport
page.content: No. 631 whose aircraft were used by the A.T.C. and A.C.F cadets. The RAF closed with little ceremony on 31st. March 1959 and deHavilland inherited it. In 1960 de Havilland attempted to produce some revenue by the encouragement of passenger services through what was now officially called "Hawarden Airport". On 3rd April 1969 Cambrian Airways revived the Chester-London service. The flight originated at Liverpool and the first sector was claimed to be one of the shortest in the world, averaging about eight minutes from take-off to touchdown at Hawarden. Sadly, the Viscount service was not a success and by December Cambrian said that they had lost Â£20,000 on the route. During one five-day period, only 26 passengers were carried to London and 28 on the return flights.
